title: Lawyers in Paterson bribery case say U.S. Attorney Habba had ‘preoccupation’ with the city
description: It's part of a push by lawyers for Cesar Pina saying an indictment should be dismissed accusing the real estate influencer of bribing a city official
content:
PATERSON — Did then-interim United States Attorney Alina Habba’s April warning — “I’m looking at you, Paterson” — result in a July indictment accusing a notorious real estate influencer of bribing a city official?

That’s the question lawyers representing the influencer, Cesar Pina, raised in a letter filed Aug. 19 in federal court in Newark. It’s part of the ongoing court battle over whether the indictment against Pina — which also included fraud and money laundering charges — should be dismissed because Habba’s interim appointment had expired before the indictment was filed.

U.S. Attorney General Pamela Bondi argued in a Aug. 18 legal brief that the dispute over the status of Habba’s appointment should not affect the Pina indictment.

“Ms. Habba did not present any evidence or the indictment to the grand jury, nor did she attend those presentations to the grand jury,” Bondi’s brief said of the Pina case.

The brief asserted that Pina’s lawyers failed to identify any other way in which Habba’s role at the U.S. Attorney’s Office affected the substance of the indictment.

The next day, Pina’s lawyers submitted a letter to the court arguing that the attorney general “opened the door” to the question of Habba’s role in the criminal probe.

During her time as interim U.S. Attorney for New Jersey, Habba made multiple public comments in news interviews about the attention she was paying to Paterson, calling it “a sanctuary city.” In May, Habba filed a lawsuit against Paterson and three other New Jersey cities — Newark, Hoboken, and Jersey City — accusing them of obstructing federal immigration officials.

Pina’s lawyers cited those actions as evidence of “Ms. Habba's apparent preoccupation with the City of Paterson,” saying it raised questions about her role in the indictment, and discussions she may have had with her underlings.

“Specifically, did they discuss the inclusion of the Paterson bribery count in the indictment?” asked Pina’s legal team, led by attorney Gerald Krovatin. “Did Ms. Habba review the prosecution memo in this case? Consistent with her public comments, did Ms. Habba instruct her prosecutors to prioritize investigations and prosecutions involving the City of Paterson?”

The federal indictment never named the Paterson official whom Pina is accused of bribing in exchange for help in getting city approvals to convert an abandoned school into housing. The project never got the approvals needed.

More: Attorneys for Bergen real estate influencer accused of fraud argue for case dismissal

More than half a dozen city officials have received subpoenas in the federal bribery probe. Paterson political insiders say the description of the city official as someone involved in real estate deals points to Councilman Alex Mendez.

In mid-July, Mendez acknowledged during a televised City Council meeting that he spoke with federal investigators, and said he has done nothing wrong.

"There's an investigation going on," Mendez said during the meeting. "I answered all the questions, and I submitted all the information. And that's it, that's what happened.”

This article originally appeared on NorthJersey.com: Paterson bribery case lawyers say Habba had ‘preoccupation’ with city
summary: Lawyers representing Cesar Pina, the real estate influencer accused of bribing a city official, have raised questions about then-interim United States Attorney Alina Habba's involvement in the case. The question is part of a court battle over whether the indictment against Pina should be dismissed as Habba’s interim appointment had expired before the indictment was filed. U.S. Attorney General Pamela Bondi argued that Habba did not present evidence or the indictment to the grand jury, nor did she attend presentations. Pina's lawyers also highlighted Habb's public comments about Paterson as an example of her focus on the city.
shortSummary: Lawyers representing Cesar Pina argue that former US Attorney Alina Habba's preoccupation with Paterson contributed to the Pina bribery case.

scraped_sources.text:
Paterson councilman breaks silence about FBI corruption probe, says he did nothing wrong
3-minute read
- A federal indictment said an unnamed city official accepted $50,000 in bribes from developer Cesar Pina in exchange for supporting a development project.
- Mendez, a licensed Realtor, used a Pina-owned building as his campaign headquarters and received a political donation from Pina in the past.
- Federal authorities issued subpoenas to at least six Paterson officials, seeking records of communication and financial dealings with Pina and his companies.
PATERSON — Councilman Alex Mendez on July 15 broke his silence about an ongoing FBI corruption probe, acknowledging that he was questioned by investigators and asserting he has done nothing wrong.
For days, Mendez has been the subject of widespread speculation after the U.S. Attorney’s Office said on July 10 that a Paterson government official — whose name has not been made public — took $50,000 in bribes from real estate influencer Cesar Pina in exchange for backing a development proposal.
Federal authorities said the Paterson official is a licensed Realtor, a description that many political insiders saw as a clue that the alleged bribe-taker was Mendez, particularly because the councilman used a building owned by Pina as his campaign headquarters in 2024 and received a $2,600 political donation from Pina in 2020.
Story continues below photo gallery.
In his comments during the July 15 City Council meeting, Mendez said he has received an outpouring of public support after his name appeared in news stories about the Pina case and noted that he was not charged in the indictment.
“There’s an investigation going on,” Mendez said in the televised meeting. “I answered all the questions, and I submitted all the information. And that’s it, that’s what happened.
“I want to say thank to all those that reached out to me, because I know that I have done nothing wrong,” Mendez continued. “I’ve been an open book in the city of Paterson. I’ve been in business, and I’ve been supporting my family. Since 2003, I’ve been a real estate agent.”
Mendez — who faces state election fraud charges in a case that has dragged on for more than five years — has not responded to repeated messages from Paterson Press about the Pina probe.
Real estate commissions among 'stream of bribes'
A federal indictment against Pina said the influencer retained the unnamed city official as his agent to use real estate commissions as “part of the stream of bribes.”
In exchange, the indictment said, the official would help Pina get Paterson zoning board approval for the investor’s proposal to convert a long-closed schoolhouse on Totowa Avenue into 60 housing units. But the project never got zoning approval.
The indictment said the unnamed city official in March 2022 deposited a check for an $18,132 commission from the sale of a Pina property.
Helped hundreds of first-time homebuyers
In his speech at the council meeting, Mendez said he has “helped hundreds of families to become first-time homebuyers” in his real estate job. He said banks, title companies and lawyers play a role in real estate sales.
The councilman said his commissions get deposited as checks in payments made by title companies through his broker. Mendez said he has been transparent in handling his real estate commissions.
The New Jersey Real Estate Commission collects information on property transactions but does not make public the commission amounts for individual sales.
“I never used this position,” Mendez said, referring to his role as a council member, “to help myself. I never go around using my title, my position, to ask people for favors. I’ve never done that.”
Mendez said he works hard and takes pride in that.
“If I like to travel, it’s my money,” the councilman said. “If I like to buy new cars, it’s my money. I work day and night. I’m a hustler.”
Range Rover purchased with stolen title
In March 2022, Mendez’s purchase of an SUV landed him in the news. The councilman disclosed at that time that he bought a 2016 Range Rover that he said he later found out had a title reported stolen in Georgia.
Mendez said he bought the vehicle through an online advertisement and paid $25,000 in cash to a man he met on Avenue N in Brooklyn. Mendez said back then that some of the money he spent on the Range Rover came from a commission he earned from his real estate work.
Mendez’s bitter political rival, former Councilman William McKoy, has often cited the Range Rover purchase as evidence of Mendez’s murky finances. McKoy said in an interview on July 16 that it was clear to him the indictment was referring to Mendez in its description of Pina’s alleged bribes.
McKoy said that while driving home on the evening of July 15 he passed the building connected to Pina that Mendez used as a campaign headquarters. For 14 months after the election, a long Mendez banner remained wrapped around the facade of the corner storefront.
The building was sold in a recent auction as part of Pina’s bankruptcy. McKoy said that while driving by the building this week he noticed the new owners had workers taking down the Mendez banner.
Six Paterson officials have gotten federal subpoenas
At least six city officials — whose names have not been made public by authorities — have received federal subpoenas in the FBI probe of Pina. The subpoenas order the officials to provide investigators with documentation of their communications — including emails, texts and phone logs — with Pina, his wife, and about three dozen of their real estate companies.
The subpoenas also cover records involving “the receipt or offer of any money, directly or indirectly,” from the Pinas and their companies as well as “any business dealings conducted in your professional or personal capacity with any of the individuals, entities or representatives.”
During his five-minute council speech, Mendez talked about “people who are praying for me to make sure that I’m OK.”
“I’m OK,” the councilman said. “I haven’t done nothing wrong, and that’s the way I walk.”
Mendez said it was easy for people with hate in their hearts to make what he said were false accusations against him.
“I’m at peace, I’m OK and I’m going to continue doing my work in my community, helping people financially through my business, helping people here in the city of Paterson, helping families, because that’s what I do,” the councilman said.

argos_summary: Cesar Pina, a real‑estate influencer, was indicted in July on bribery, fraud, and money‑laundering charges that allegedly involved a Paterson city official. Pina’s lawyers argue the indictment should be dismissed because interim U.S. Attorney Alina Habba’s appointment had expired before it was filed, citing her public focus on Paterson and a lawsuit she filed against the city. U.S. Attorney General Pamela Bondi rejected the argument, saying Habba did not present evidence to the grand jury and her role did not affect the indictment. Meanwhile, Paterson Councilman Alex Mendez, suspected of receiving a $50,000 bribe, has denied wrongdoing and said he cooperated with investigators.
